comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: On 1 April 1911 at Imtarfa Barracks in Malta, Captain J C Scott took over from Captain G. A. McL. Sceales as Adjutant of 1st Battalion Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders.  He was therefore a pre-war Regular soldier - though he does not appear to have commanded the First Battalion on active service during the First World War.  He wears a gold wound stripe on his left lower sleeve.//

comment.author: 78785369@N06
comment._content: The London Gazette of 20th July 1915, on Page 7174 of Edition 29238, records a Captain John C. Scott serving in the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: This is probably Lieutenant Colonel John Creagh Scott OBE DSO.  He was from Killadysert, County Clare, Ireland.//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Lieutenant-Colonel John Creagh Scott, D.S.O., O.B.E., served with the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders in the South African War and was seriously wounded.  In the First World War, on promotion to Lt Col in 1916, he took over temporary command, in June 1916, of the combined battalion of 5/6th Royal Scots Fusiliers, one of which had been the command of Winston Churchill, this after Churchill had been appointed to an important post at home and just before the Battle of the Somme.

In addition to other distinctions Lt Col Scott received the Croix de Guerre avec Etoile d'Or and was Mentioned in Despatches six times. He was latterly a member of the the National Farmers Union, the Irish Farmers Federation, and the National Agricultural and Industrial Development Association of Eire.  He wrote a book "Hidden Government" published in 1954.//

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
John Creagh Scott DSO OBE died 6 December 1957 at Langhill, Moretonhampstead, Devon according to the National Probate Calendar. Probate granted to Joan Mary Lethbridge Scott, widow and John James Scott, research scientist.

Death record shows he was born circa 1879.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Buried in St Andrew’s Church Cemetery, South Tawton, Devon www.gravestonephotos.com/public/gravedetails.php?availabl...
